message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has been experiencing “feeling down” since his girlfriend broke up with him 4 years ago, indicating persistent depressive disorder. The symptoms have been present for at least two years, thus fulfilling the criteria for diagnosis of persistent depressive disorder. Major depressive disorder would require the presence of several additional symptoms, such as appetite or sleep disturbance, which are absent in this case. Cyclothymic disorder involves periods of both hypomania and depression, and the patient does not report any symptoms of hypomania. Adjustment disorder with depressed mood would be a possibility if the onset of symptoms had occurred within three months of the breakup.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has been feeling down for 4 years, which is longer than the criteria for major depressive disorder. The absence of manic or hypomanic episodes rules out cyclothymic disorder. The patient's symptoms meet the criteria for persistent depressive disorder, which is characterized by a depressed mood that lasts for at least 2 years. Adjustment disorder with depressed mood is a possibility, but the duration of the patient's symptoms makes persistent depressive disorder a more likely diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The persistent nature of the patient’s symptoms for the last 4 years is suggestive of persistent depressive disorder. Major depressive disorder is characterized by symptoms lasting at least 2 weeks, while cyclothymic disorder involves periods of hypomanic and depressive symptoms. Adjustment disorder with depressed mood typically occurs in response to a specific stressor and lasts less than 6 months.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has been feeling down for a period of more than 2 years and has had only a few periods of relief. This suggests persistent depressive disorder, formerly known as dysthymia. Major depressive disorder would require at least one major depressive episode, and the patient has not described any manic or hypomanic episodes, ruling out cyclothymic disorder. The symptoms do not suggest an acute stressor, ruling out adjustment disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has been feeling down for a long time and has had difficulty concentrating and sleeping, which suggests a persistent depressive disorder. The symptoms have lasted for more than 2 years, ruling out major depressive disorder and adjustment disorder. Cyclothymic disorder is characterized by periods of hypomanic and depressive symptoms, which is not present in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia), as they have persisted for more than 2 years with episodic periods of normal mood. Major depressive disorder and adjustment disorder with depressed mood are not correct diagnoses because the symptoms have persisted for a longer period. Cyclothymic disorder is not the correct diagnosis because the patient does not have any symptoms of hypomania or mania.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia) as he has been feeling down most of the time for the past 4 years, with only a few periods of time without feeling that way. Major depressive disorder is characterized by depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day, for at least 2 weeks. Cyclothymic disorder involves periods of hypomania and periods of depressive symptoms. Adjustment disorder with depressed mood is a temporary reaction to a stressful life event, such as a breakup, and typically lasts less than 6 months.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest persistent depressive disorder, as the feelings of sadness have persisted for more than 2 years without significant relief. Major depressive disorder usually lasts for a shorter period of time, less than 2 years. Cyclothymic disorder involves periods of hypomania and depression, which is not described in this case. Adjustment disorder with depressed mood is usually a reaction to a specific stressor, such as the breakup with his girlfriend, but the duration of symptoms is shorter than what is described here.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has been feeling down for a long time (since the breakup with his girlfriend 4 years ago) but doesn't report any issues with appetite, weight or energy, which rules out major depressive disorder. The duration and severity of symptoms suggest persistent depressive disorder. There is no evidence for cyclothymic disorder or adjustment disorder with depressed mood.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms have persisted for at least 2 years, which rules out Major depressive disorder and Adjustment disorder with depressed mood. The absence of hypomanic or manic symptoms rules out Cyclothymic disorder. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is Persistent depressive disorder, also known as dysthymia.
